items.title: From your brother who has been almost doing what you did for almost 20 years, just go do it, build…
items.description:
From your brother who has been almost doing what you did for almost 20 years, just go do it, build something, fail a gazillion times and then finish it. This is the story of those who really want to achieve something, they just went for it, and it is also a sign of a future that is getting closer where the traditional academy does not exist any more.

If you ever hit a brick wall, don’t hesitate to ask me something, most likely I’ve hit that brick wall myself too.

God bless you man!

items.title: Beautiful post. Couldn’t have stated it better.
items.description: Beautiful post. Couldn’t have stated it better.

items.title: Data vs. Vision.
items.description: Data vs. Vision. Two different approaches to solving a problem. Both valid, not necessarily antagonic. Neither of the two is the valid answer. Some designers like one, some the other. What you have to concede, is even by having extensive user research there is no guarantee that the end product will be useful, cause you still have the interpretation of a human being translating the data onto something. That’s why some like to skip it and start interpreting right away. Vision also comes from interpreting historical references and similar solutions to be adapted to solve the problem, so essentially it’s not a research-less path.

items.title: React, Redux, Connect, Router
items.description: Just wanted to get my head around Redux, plus establishing the proper connection to the component with the react-redux tools  while also fiddling with some Material Design Lite.

items.title: I happen to agree with you.
items.description:
I happen to agree with you. I guess it’s architecture school that trained me like this. Build something tangible, iterate fast. It’s how I roll and how I perform best. Although it has certainly looked as a disadvantage to certain roles in the design Industry, so those who think like you and me, have got to define ourselves as innovators, not researches, we have to declare up front that we work best when there’s little to gather data from.

I think of this as an advantage, but also look at every other process as valuable, every designer feels comfortable with certain rules to approach a problem.

There is certainly an advantage in front of the customer, and this I have tested in a project where there was another firm competing for the same gig, while they were mute gathering information and pasting stickies on the wall, we were already discussing components, technology and visual refinement with the customer, we even skipped the wire framing and delivered hifi every sprint. At the end of the race, we had a full fledged realistic prototype while the other agency had personas, catchy sentences and lofi wires.

We won that project… …we actually crushed them.

items.title: Design is not exempt from trends, nor critique.
items.description:
Design is not exempt from trends, nor critique.

Not everyone will like your design decisions, and that's why there's a complex and rich history of art.

As a designer you should be aware of that and not expect the design community to agree with you all the time. Once you have come to terms with that reality only time will grant you with the answer if what you did was good or bad.

If you are uncomfortable with the social and media repercussions of your work, then you should have picked math or physics as a career.

And just a little quote to round this up:

"It took me four years to paint like Raphael, but a lifetime to paint like a child."
Pablo Picasso

items.title: Second article of yours I respond to today.
items.description:
Second article of yours I respond to today.

The design procces is not always like you describe it. And that’s a good thing, cause then it would be always driven by a statistical approach. If design was like that then we all could say that you might as well fire your UX designer and make the UI guy use an A/B testing engine. Maybe it could cost more resources at first, but the statistical streamlining would enhance the product so much that you’d get your money back on the long run.

I like how vocal you are in defense of your method, but being a good designer is also recognizing that there are other ways to solve a problem which is what design stands for.

items.title: In architecture you drive UX through UI, maybe that’s the key in the marriage of both, having the…
items.description:
In architecture you drive UX through UI, maybe that’s the key in the marriage of both, having the process to flow backwards, by creating UI to define the UX.

I guess design is different from other fields because allows you to do that.
